												Deathmatch Classic was a mod for Half-Life created by Valve software alongside others like Team Fortress Classic and Day of Defeat. Unfortunately it was never as popular as some of the others and quietly faded back into obscurity.DMC is essentially a remake of the multiplayer component of Quake 1 using Half-Life's particular GoldSrc engine. Including remade versions of Quake 1's various weapons, such as the nailgun, super shotgun and rocket launcher. It uses a lot of Half-life's assets like multiplayer models, textures and sprites. And at the same time attempts to mimic Quake's physics. Allowing players to also bunnyhop and strafejump. They also remade several of Quake 1's deathmatch maps and included them with the game.Now all of this was great. Although Deathmatch Classic released at around the same time as Quake 3 and Unreal Tournament. As a result the community didn't really gravitate towards it as much as Valve would have liked, seeing it as a little outdated and more of a novelty.  Playing it today you can see some general upsides to Deathmatch Classic. It uses Steam's server browser and has mods for bots. So it is rather easy to setup a game of classic Quake deathmatch with someone online. But the playerbase is extinct, and as a result it's just another relic in Valve's catalogue

												With the Quake engine being the basis for the legendary Goldsrc engine, bringing us timeless classics such as Half Life and Counter Strike, it was nice to see VALVE paying tribute to the folks that made their games possible to begin with ! He subsequently managed to consolidate power following the 1924 death of Vladimir Lenin through suppressing Lenin's criticisms (in the postscript of his testament) and expanding the functions of his role, all the while eliminating any opposition. He remained general secretary until the post was abolished in 1952, concurrently serving as the Premier of the Soviet Union from 1941 onward.Under Stalin's rule, the concept of "socialism in one country" became a central tenet of Soviet society. He replaced the New Economic Policy introduced by Lenin in the early 1920s with a highly centralised command economy, launching a period of industrialization and collectivization that resulted in the rapid transformation of the USSR from an agrarian society into an industrial power.[2] However, the economic changes coincided with the imprisonment of millions of people in correctional labour camps.[3] The initial upheaval in agriculture disrupted food production and contributed to the catastrophic Soviet famine of 1932–1933, known as the Holodomor in Ukraine. Between 1934 and 1939 he organized and led a massive purge (known as "Great Purge") of the party, government, armed forces and intelligentsia, in which millions of so-called "enemies of the Soviet people" were imprisoned, exiled or executed. Despite heavy human and territorial losses, Soviet forces managed to halt the Nazi incursion after the decisive Battles of Moscow and Stalingrad. After defeating the Axis powers on the Eastern Front, the Red Army captured Berlin in May 1945, effectively ending the war in Europe for the Allies.[5][6] The Soviet Union subsequently emerged as one of two recognized world superpowers, the other being the United States.[7] The Yalta and Potsdam conferences established communist governments loyal to the Soviet Union in the Eastern Bloc countries as buffer states. Long story short: It's a copy and paste port of Quake's Deathmatch mode into Valve's Goldsource engine with less maps, less mods, and no singleplayer. Skip it and grab Quake instead.DISCLAIMER: As an Australian, the playerbase is almost non-existant. While playable with 4 to 8 friends, you won't enjoy this game as much if you're by yourself.Deathmatch Classic is essentially just a deathmatch type game mode using Quake's weapons (and some of its maps). It feels like it was an experiment to recreate Quake inside Valve's new engine than anything else, because it lacks any sort of content unique to the experience.Not that there's anything wrong with this game: Quake's multiplayer is some of the best there is. There's a bunch of cool weapons, each for different playstyles and situations, and the maps give a nice sense of dynamic movement. It's quick, fast, and tonnes of fun.The issue here is that Deathmatch Classic doesn't add anything other than a couple of maps. They're still good, but the issue is that for $5, you're playing a thinned down experience of the multiplayer portion of an 18 year old game that is available on the same platform. As part of the Counter-Strike 1 Anthology, it's an okay bonus, but as a standalone title it's not worth the price.RATING: 0 UP, 1 DOWNMy up/down rating system tries to differentiate between games that are mediocre (less ups and downs total), and games that are interesting but flawed (more ups and downs totals). 												Deathmatch Classic is a multiplayer DM action on HL1 engine, copying almost one to one Deathmatch of Quake 1. It was a free modification that came with patch for Half-Life back when it had retail release, yet as of right now it's being sold serapately on Steam.And I must announce first, the Internet community here is almost dead. Not worth the purchase, I am afraid. Most often, you will see a list of completely empty servers, only sometimes getting 1-3 players playing on one server.But yes, what you see here is almost complete copy of Quake 1 Deathmatch experience - a Valve's tribute of it, with same weapons, same maps even, close textures. But it's now shinier and a bit slower-paced. You get same maps. You get same weapons, but they look quite HD compared to Quake 1 style. You know them, shotguns, nailguns, grenade and rocket launchers. And as you know, rocket launcher is really the best weapon here, can't really hope to hit all time with weak projectile weapon that is Nailgun, while Rockets provide heavy-damaging splash effect anywhere you point at. Another thing, is that high-ping is quite unfriendly in this game, you can only hope to do damage with rockets. So yes, Rocket Launcher is overpowered and main thing there, like in Quake 1.  Otherwise, classic Arena formula. Stock, shoot, then run and restock. It's quite fun to duel, combatting and juggling with rockets and then getting away to restock health and armor, taking best on map.Now, if only it wasn't so dead...

A good remake at that.-Tight controls, an array of weapons, and tricks are carried over from Quake, so you will own people if you were good back in the day.-Can run on a potato and still look decent.-Can have an assortment of different pings and still play smoothly during matches.-Decent texture quality for the maps.-Good customization of your character for rounds. You can choose to play as Gman or Gordan Freeman, as well as some other characters from the original Half Life.-Good fun for you and your friends if you want an interesting "blast from the past" during a LAN party.-Comes with a few bundles so you can snag this game for next to nothing while getting some of Valve's top work.Cons-No one plays it enough to find a lively match.-Too few servers to actually play on, but thankfully there are servers to begin with.-While the maps are mainly ports of Quake maps without their more explicit, pixel-heavy graphics, there are only around 6-8 maps total, not including Custom maps though. -Since there aren't really many matches at all, you won't really have the opportunity to enjoy this game.Other topics-Outdated gameplay mechanics by today's standards, but perfect by the logic of the original games produced by Id Software.-Weapon selection, while restricted to the original weapon selection from Quake, can become stale for more modern players.The verdict is...... Get it only in a bundle. I loved Quake, and I loved what little bit I get from this. The game offers so much, but can only really do so when you have others to play against.
